awd_titl_txt: Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will continue research activity on the development of various aspects of mathematical analysis which are relevant to some of the most fundamental problems in the area of harmonic analysis and partial differential equations and its applications. The project will also continue the training of graduate students and postdoctoral students to carry out research in these problems. Many of the topics to be studied have their origin in problems coming from physics and engineering. It is expected that the research proposed will have a synergistic effect between these fields and the mathematical fields of analysis and geometry.

The main focus of the research will be the study of soliton resolution for the energy critical wave equation and the wave map equation, both in the presence and the absence of symmetry, and for other dispersive and dispersive-geometric models. In another direction, a study will be made of quantitative unique continuation in local settings and at infinity, including the cases of periodic and random coefficients, and their connection with homogenization theory. This is a very ambitious program of research that will have lasting consequences for the development of these areas. The principal investigator will ensure the wide dissemination of the results obtained, including their use in the development of courses, the training of graduate students and postdocs, and the exploration of the connections with other fields of science and technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this project is the development of new ideas and methods to understand a variety of problems in nonlinear dispersive equations, centering on the behavior of large solutions, for large time. The area of nonlinear dispersive equations originates in fields such as nonlinear wave propagation, particle physics, nonlinear elasticity and general relativity. In the area of nonlinear wave and dispersive equations, the PI and collaborators developed powerful new ideas and methods that have already had a broad impact in the field. With these new methods, the PI and collaborators have been able to solve long-standing problems on singularity formation and long-time asymptotics, leading to the solution of the soliton resolution conjecture in some cases.

The broad impact of this project is both scientific and educational. On the scientific side, the results and methods developed in this project will have impact in related fields such as optics, lasers, mathematical physics and water waves. On the educational side, the PI has developed graduate courses based on this research. In addition, the PI has lectured extensively and has taught a number of summer courses based on this research. The results of the PI's research on this project have been widely disseminated through publication in leading specialized journals, the posting of preprints in electronic preprint servers and the PI's webpage. In addition, the PI has written a large number of survey papers giving expository accounts of his results on this project. The PI has been very actively involved in the training of young researchers on topics related to the project. During the duration of this project, the PI has supervised 4 graduate students, on topics related to this grant, with two of them completing their PhD during this project, and the third one being expected to graduate in 2022. The PI has also supervised and collaborated extensively with postdoctoral researchers, having supervised 9 of them during this grant period, on projects related to this grant.
